newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy names new public works minister.
newsitem.headline: Italy names new public works minister.

text.p: Italian President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro on Wednesday swore in a university professor as new public works minister to replace former graft-busting magistrate Antonio Di Pietro who resigned last week in a corruption probe.
The president's office named the new minister as Paolo Costa, the rector of the Ca' Foscari University in Venice.

Costa, 53, studied economics in Venice and Paris and has taught in Britain and Italy. He has collaborated on a public works project for the Venice lagoon and worked on the technical elaboration of a national transport plan.

Di Pietro, a non-elected technocrat and one of Italy's most popular public figures, stormed out of government last Thursday after coming under investigation for alleged malpractice during his time with Milan's "Clean Hands" pool of magistrates.
Investigations by the team unearthed the "Tangentopoli" (Bribesville) scandals in the early 1990s that toppled Italy's corrupt ruling old guard.

Di Pietro came under investigation in an earlier judicial probe but a court dropped all charges against him. He denies wrongdoing and has vowed to clear his name and defend the work of the elite Clean Hands team he spearheaded.
Prime Minister Romano Prodi had tried to persuade Di Pietro to reconsider but the impulsive former magistrate, who quit the judiciary two years ago with no explanation, flatly refused.
